citations.narrative:
Several of the walls in the indoor dog areas are in a state of disrepair. In the medium sized room, housing seven dogs,
there is a large hole, approximately 8" x 12", in the wall adjacent to the whelping area. On the other side of the whelping
area, there are two additional holes in the wall which are approximately 3"x 2" and 5"x2" in size. In the large dog room,
housing five dogs, there is an area of dry wall, to the left of the main door, that is damaged and has exposed untreated
wood. Lastly, in the small dog room, housing five dogs, there is a hole, approximately 2"x1", in the dry wall in the right
corner behind the dog bed.
Dog housing facilities which have holes and areas of disrepair can lead to entrapment, chewing and ingestion of foreign
materials, or injury to the animals.
Housing facilities for dogs must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound and kept in good repair to
protect the animals from injury. Correct by repairing the walls to ensure that they are structurally sound for the dogs.
Correct by: October 23, 2025.

There are several areas of rust in the dog rooms. In the medium sized room, there is a dog bed with large metal clamps
used to secure a blanket which are completely covered in rust. Near the entrance to this room, the bottoms of the white
gates are rusted and have started to flake. In the large dog room, the bottom of the main door is deteriorating due to rust
and appears pitted. In the small dog enclosure, there is an additional dog bed with rusted metal clamps.
Surfaces within dog enclosures that have excessive amounts of rust can affect the structural integrity of the enclosure and
make it difficult to properly clean which could lead to injury or disease conditions in the dogs.
Interior surfaces and any surfaces that come in contact with dogs or cats must be free of excessive rust that prevents the
required cleaning and sanitization or that affects the structural strength of the surface. Correct by removing, repairing, or
replacing the rusted surfaces in the dog areas.
Correct by: October 23, 2025.

The program of veterinary care does not include a schedule for sampling of parasites for the dogs. The facility performs
occasional parasite sampling if illness is observed, but they do not have a routine sampling scheduled approved by their
attending veterinarian at this time.
Routine sampling for parasites and other pests is important to ensure the overall health of the adult dogs.
The written program of veterinary care must include sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests (including fleas,
worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian. Correct
by including a veterinary approved sampling schedule for parasites within your program of vet care.
Correct by: October 7, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Several of the walls in the indoor dog areas are in a state of disrepair. In the medium sized room, housing seven dogs, 
there is a large hole, approximately 8" x 12", in the wall adjacent to the whelping area. On the other side of the whelping 
area, there are two additional holes in the wall which are approximately 3"x 2" and 5"x2" in size. In the large dog room, 
housing five dogs, there is an area of dry wall, to the left of the main door, that is damaged and has exposed untreated 
wood. Lastly, in the small dog room, housing five dogs, there is a hole, approximately 2"x1", in the dry wall in the right 
corner behind the dog bed.  
Dog housing facilities which have holes and areas of disrepair can lead to entrapment, chewing and ingestion of foreign 
materials, or injury to the animals. 
Housing facilities for dogs must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound and kept in good repair to 
protect the animals from injury. Correct by repairing the walls to ensure that they are structurally sound for the dogs.  
Correct by: October 23, 2025. 
3.1(c)(1)(i) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There are several areas of rust in the dog rooms. In the medium sized room, there is a dog bed with large metal clamps 
used to secure a blanket which are completely covered in rust. Near the entrance to this room, the bottoms of the white 
gates are rusted and have started to flake. In the large dog room, the bottom of the main door is deteriorating due to rust 
and appears pitted. In the small dog enclosure, there is an additional dog bed with rusted metal clamps.  
Surfaces within dog enclosures that have excessive amounts of rust can affect the structural integrity of the enclosure and 
make it difficult to properly clean which could lead to injury or disease conditions in the dogs.  
Interior surfaces and any surfaces that come in contact with dogs or cats must be free of excessive rust that prevents the 
required cleaning and sanitization or that affects the structural strength of the surface. Correct by removing, repairing, or 
replacing the rusted surfaces in the dog areas.  
Correct by: October 23, 2025. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs.

The program of veterinary care does not include a schedule for sampling of parasites for the dogs. The facility performs 
occasional parasite sampling if illness is observed, but they do not have a routine sampling scheduled approved by their 
attending veterinarian at this time.  
Routine sampling for parasites and other pests is important to ensure the overall health of the adult dogs.  
The written program of veterinary care must include sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests (including fleas, 
worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm) in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian. Correct 
by including a veterinary approved sampling schedule for parasites within your program of vet care.  
Correct by: October 7, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
